p: The island of Hispaniola, shared by Haiti and the Dominican Republic, included in 2016 around 217,000 people living with the human immunodeficiency virus-type 1 (HIV-1), the etiologic agent of the acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) ( UNAIDS, 2013, 2017). Initially, AIDS cases recognized in Haiti ( Pape et al., 1983) and the Dominican Republic ( Koenig et al., 1987) mostly involved men who had sex with men, but these countries now have generalized epidemics predominantly driven by heterosexual sex ( Figueroa, 2008). Despite the high HIV prevalence rates reported for the general population in Haiti (2.1%: 1.9–2.3%) and the Dominican Republic (1.0%: 0.7–1.4%) in 2016, significant declines of the HIV incidence rates were observed in both countries over the last decade ( UNAIDS, 2013, 2017).
